Desert Noises are a four piece group out of Utah who play alternative rock with a heavy dose of folk aesthetic. The groupÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s alternative folk style might beg an immediate comparison to acts like Fleet Foxes or Local Natives, though Desert Noises also often straddle the gap between moments of pop and even psychedelic rock. Front-man Kyle Henderson has a rich voice with a certain aged quality that adds a touch of melancholy, reflecting the lyrical content. Henderson croons about heartbreak, falling in and out of love, and displays a constant love for evoking simple nature metaphors. The instrumentals on Mountain Sea are always tastefully playful, with auxiliary instruments occasionally adding richness to these very groovy songs. The guitarists and rhythm section do a wonderful job of creating a sound thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s familiar but a little more aggressively groovy than other similar bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s output. The musicianship is consistently superb, but occasionally the production feels a little too familiar to the point where itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not doing much for the mostly intriguing songwriting. Through the whole of Mountain Sea there are well placed, albeit simple, harmonies and a sense of momentum that early releases from bands rarely are able to convey. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s clear Desert Noises meant to craft an album with a concrete beginning building to an end, but Mountain Sea has me even more excited about where theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll go next time, as opposed to where weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve left off here. But for now, Mountain Sea will satiate this desire just fine with itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pleasant musicianship and deceptively engrossing lyricism.
